versions.name: TLS 1.3
versions.summary: Latest TLS revision with shorter handshakes and forward secrecy by default.
versions.compatibility: Supported by browsers and OS releases from 2018 onward. Older appliances may require firmware updates but most managed providers enable it.
versions.usage: Enable by default and prefer for all clients. Keep TLS 1.2 only for legacy compatibility.

versions.name: TLS 1.2
versions.summary: Mature workhorse version still required for older clients.
versions.compatibility: Universally supported, including legacy Java 8, Windows Server 2012, and embedded stacks.
versions.usage: Keep as fallback with a restricted cipher list. Plan migrations to retire it as clients update.

versions.name: TLS 1.1
versions.summary: Legacy protocol lacking modern ciphers and features.
versions.compatibility: Disabled by default in current browsers; only very old clients still rely on it.
versions.usage: Disable entirely. If a legacy system mandates it, isolate the traffic and plan an upgrade.

versions.name: TLS 1.0
versions.summary: Deprecated protocol vulnerable to BEAST and similar attacks.
versions.compatibility: Unsupported in modern browsers and compliance frameworks such as PCI DSS.
versions.usage: Must remain disabled. Replace or upgrade systems that still require it.

ciphers.name: TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
ciphers.summary: AEAD cipher suite for TLS 1.3 using 256-bit AES-GCM.
ciphers.compatibility: Available wherever TLS 1.3 is negotiated. Hardware acceleration common on servers and desktops.
ciphers.usage: Offer alongside TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256. Use when compliance calls for 256-bit keys.

ciphers.name: TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256
ciphers.summary: TLS 1.3 cipher optimized for mobile and CPU-constrained clients.
ciphers.compatibility: Excellent performance on mobile ARM devices; supported by Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and OpenSSL 1.1.1+.
ciphers.usage: Keep enabled as an alternative for clients without AES acceleration.

ciphers.name: TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
ciphers.compatibility: Works with modern browsers, Java 8u51+, OpenSSL 1.0.1+, and Windows Server 2012.
ciphers.usage: Keep as the default TLS 1.2 option when RSA certificates are in use.

ciphers.name: TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
ciphers.summary: ECDSA certificate with AES-256-GCM for TLS 1.2.
ciphers.compatibility: Requires ECDSA server certificates and client support (Chrome, Firefox, iOS 11+, Android 7+).
ciphers.usage: Enable for environments issuing ECDSA certificates to get smaller handshake sizes.

ciphers.name: TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA
ciphers.summary: Legacy 3DES CBC cipher without forward secrecy.
ciphers.compatibility: Only present on outdated stacks; fails modern compliance benchmarks.
ciphers.usage: Remove from configurations. If a device still relies on it, segment and upgrade urgently.
